ai-sn21:1.1.2_0: At one time the Buddha was staying near Sāvatthī in Jeta’s Grove, Anāthapiṇḍika’s monastery.
ai-sn21:1.1.3_0: There Venerable Mahāmoggallāna addressed the mendicants:
ai-sn21:1.2.2_0: “Just now, reverends, as I was in private retreat this thought came to mind:
ai-sn21:1.2.3_0: ‘He is called a noble one’, while maintaining silence in silence.
ai-sn21:1.2.4_0: What then is this noble silence?’
ai-sn21:1.2.5_0: Then this, friend, occurred to me:
ai-sn21:1.2.6_0: ‘As the placing of the mind and keeping it connected are stilled, a mendicant enters and remains in the second absorption, which has the rapture and bliss born of immersion, with internal clarity and confidence, and unified mind, without placing the mind and keeping it connected.
ai-sn21:1.2.8_0: And so, as the placing of the mind and keeping it connected were stilled, I was entering and remaining in the second absorption, which has the rapture and bliss born of immersion, with internal clarity and confidence, and unified mind, without placing the mind and keeping it connected.
ai-sn21:1.2.9_0: While I was in that meditation, perceptions and attentions accompanied by placing the mind beset me.
ai-sn21:1.3.1_0: Then the Buddha came up to me with his psychic power and said,
ai-sn21:1.3.2_0: ‘Moggallāna, Moggallāna! Don’t neglect noble silence, brahmin! Settle your mind in noble silence; unify your mind and bring it to immersion in noble silence.’
ai-sn21:1.3.3_0: And so, after some time ... I was entering and remaining in the second absorption.
ai-sn21:1.3.4_0: For if anyone should be rightly called
ai-sn21:1.3.5_0: a disciple who attained to great direct knowledge with help from the Teacher, it’s me.”
ai-sn21:1.3.6_0: ‘Socializing the big sacrifices of A disciple who attained to great direct knowledge.’”
ai-sn21:2.2.1_0: “Just now, reverends, as I was in private retreat this thought came to mind:
ai-sn21:2.2.2_0: ‘Is there anything in the world whose changing and perishing would give rise to sorrow, lamentation, pain, sadness, and distress in me?’
ai-sn21:2.2.3_0: Then this, friend, occurred to me:
ai-sn21:2.2.4_0: ‘There is no such thing in the world whose changing and perishing would give rise to sorrow, lamentation, pain, sadness, and distress in me.’”
ai-sn21:2.3.1_0: When he said this, Venerable Ānanda said to him,
ai-sn21:2.3.2_0: “Even if the Teacher were to decay and perish? Wouldn’t that give rise to sorrow, lamentation, pain, sadness, and distress in you?”
ai-sn21:2.3.3_0: “Even if the Teacher were to decay and perish? Wouldn’t that give rise to sorrow, lamentation, pain, sadness, and distress in me?
ai-sn21:2.3.4_0: ‘Alas, the illustrious Teacher, so mighty and powerful, has vanished!
ai-sn21:2.3.5_0: If the Buddha was to remain for a long time, that would be for the welfare and happiness of the people, for the benefit, welfare, and happiness of gods and humans.’”
ai-sn21:2.3.6_0: “That must be because Venerable Sāriputta has long ago totally eradicated ego, possessiveness, and the underlying tendency to conceit.
ai-sn21:2.3.7_0: So even if the Teacher were to decay and perish, it wouldn’t give rise to sorrow, lamentation, pain, sadness, and distress in him.”
ai-sn21:3.1.2_0: At one time the Buddha was staying near Sāvatthī in Jeta’s Grove, Anāthapiṇḍika’s monastery.
ai-sn21:3.1.3_0: At that time Venerables Sāriputta and Moggallāna were staying near Rājagaha, in the Bamboo Grove, the squirrels’ feeding ground.
ai-sn21:3.1.4_0: Then in the late afternoon, Venerable Sāriputta came out of retreat, went to Venerable Moggallāna,
ai-sn21:3.1.4_1: and after going, he exchanged greetings with venerable Mahāmoggallāna.
ai-sn21:3.1.5_0: and after exchanging courteous talk and greetings, he sat down on one side.
ai-sn21:3.2.1_0: “Reverend Moggallāna, your faculties are so very clear, and your complexion is pure and bright.
ai-sn21:3.2.2_0: Have you spent the day in a peaceful meditation?”
ai-sn21:3.2.3_0: “Reverend, I’ve spent the day in a coarse meditation.
ai-sn21:3.2.4_0: But I have had some Dhamma talk.”
ai-sn21:3.2.5_0: “Who did you have a Dhamma talk with?”
ai-sn21:3.2.7_0: “But Reverend, the Buddha is far away. He’s staying near Sāvatthī in Jeta’s Grove, Anāthapiṇḍika’s monastery.
ai-sn21:3.2.8_0: Did you go to him with your psychic power,
ai-sn21:3.2.9_0: or did he come to you?”
ai-sn21:3.2.10_0: “No reverend, I didn’t go to him with my psychic power,
ai-sn21:3.2.11_0: And the Fortunate One didn’t approach me with his psychic power,
ai-sn21:3.2.12_0: Rather, the Buddha cleared his clairvoyance and clairaudience towards me,
ai-sn21:3.2.13_0: as far as the Buddha extends, clairvoyance is purified and superhuman.”
ai-sn21:3.2.14_0: “But what manner of Dhamma talk did you have together?”
ai-sn21:3.3.4_0: When I said this, the Buddha said,
ai-sn21:3.3.5_0: ‘Moggallāna, it’s when a mendicant lives with energy roused up:
ai-sn21:3.3.6_0: “Gladly, let only skin, sinews, and bones remain! Let the flesh and blood waste away in my body! I will not stop trying until I have achieved what is possible by human strength, energy, and vigor.”
ai-sn21:3.3.7_0: That’s how a energetic person is energetic.’
ai-sn21:3.3.8_0: That’s the Dhamma talk I had together with the Buddha.”
ai-sn21:3.4.1_0: “Reverends, suppose there was a small size of the Himalayas, the king of mountains. It was laid down on the slopes of the Himalayas,
ai-sn21:3.4.3_0: Venerable Mahāmoggallāna is so mighty and powerful he could, if he wished, live on for the eon.”
ai-sn21:3.5.1_0: “Reverend, next to Venerable Sāriputta I’m like a few grains of salt next to a mound of salt.
ai-sn21:3.5.2_0: In the same way, we passed away to Venerable Sāriputta’s son.
ai-sn21:3.5.3_0: Venerable Sāriputta has been commended, complimented, and praised by the Buddha:
ai-sn21:3.7.1_0: And so these two spiritual giants agreed with each others’ fine words.
ai-sn21:4.1.2_0: Now at that time a certain junior monk, after his meal, on his return from alms-round, entered his dwelling, where he adhered to passivity and silence. And he didn’t help the mendicants out when it was time to sew robes.
ai-sn21:4.1.3_0: Then many monks went to the Fortunate One,
ai-sn21:4.1.3_1: After bowing down to the Buddha, they sat down,
ai-sn21:4.1.4_0: “Sir, after his meal, on his return from alms-round, a mendicant enters his dwelling, where they adhered to passivity and silence.”
ai-sn21:4.2.1_0: Then the Fortunate One addressed a certain monk, (saying):
ai-sn21:4.2.2_0: “Please, monk, in my name tell that monk that the Teacher summons him.”
ai-sn21:4.2.3_1: and after going, he said this to that monk:
ai-sn21:4.2.5_2: He went to the Buddha, bowed, and sat down to one side. The Buddha said to him:
ai-sn21:4.2.6_0: “Is it really true, monk, that after your meal, on your return from alms-round, you entered your dwelling, where you adhered to passivity and silence, and you didn’t help the mendicants out when it was time to sew robes?”
ai-sn21:4.2.7_0: “Sir, I am doing my own work.”
ai-sn21:4.3.1_0: Then the Buddha, knowing what that monk was thinking, addressed the mendicants:
ai-sn21:4.3.3_0: This monk gets the four absorptions—blissful meditations in the present life that belong to the higher mind—when he wants, without trouble or difficulty. He has realized the supreme culmination of the spiritual path in this very life, and lives having achieved with his own insight the goal for which gentlemen rightly go forth from the lay life to homelessness.”
ai-sn21:4.4.1_0: That is what the Buddha said.

ai-sn21:5.1.7_0: That is what the Buddha said.

ai-sn21:7.1.2_0: At one time the Buddha was staying near Vesālī, at the Great Wood, in the hall with the peaked roof.
ai-sn21:7.1.3_0: Now at that time Venerable Visākha, Pañcāli’s son, was educating, encouraging, firing up, and inspiring the mendicants in the assembly hall with a Dhamma talk. His words were polished, clear, articulate, expressing the meaning, comprehensive, and independent.
ai-sn21:7.2.1_0: Then in the late afternoon, the Buddha came out of retreat and went to the assembly hall.
ai-sn21:7.2.1_1: and after going, he sat down on the prepared seat.
ai-sn21:7.2.3_0: “Who is inspiring the mendicants with a Dhamma talk?”
ai-sn21:7.2.4_0: “Sir, it was Venerable Visākha, Pañcāli’s son.”
ai-sn21:7.3.1_0: Then the Buddha addressed Venerable Visākha,
ai-sn21:7.3.3_0: It’s good that you educate, encourage, fire up, and inspire the mendicants in the assembly hall with a Dhamma talk ...
ai-sn21:7.3.3_1: clearly independent, that is independent, untied, irreversible, and fit to stand.”
ai-sn21:7.4.1_0: That is what the Buddha said.
ai-sn21:7.4.2_0: Then the Holy One, the Teacher, went on to say:
ai-sn21:7.5.2_0: they don’t know unless he speaks.
ai-sn21:7.6.1_0: He should speak and illustrate the teaching,

ai-sn21:7.6.3_0: Words well spoken are the hermits’ banner,
ai-sn21:7.6.4_0: for the teaching is the banner of the hermits.”
ai-sn21:8.1.2_0: Then Venerable Nanda—the Buddha’s cousin on his mother’s side—dressed in nicely pressed and ironed robes, applied eyeshadow, and took a polished black bowl.
ai-sn21:8.1.2_2: He went to the Buddha, bowed, and sat down to one side. The Buddha said to him:
ai-sn21:8.1.3_0: “Nanda, as a gentleman who has gone forth in faith from the lay life to homelessness, it’s not appropriate for you to dress in nicely pressed and ironed robes, apply eyeshadow, and carry a polished black bowl.
ai-sn21:8.1.4_0: It’s appropriate for you to stay in the wilderness, eat only alms-food, wear rag robes, and live without concern for sensual pleasures.”
ai-sn21:8.1.5_0: That is what the Buddha said.
ai-sn21:8.1.6_0: The Teacher said to her: “Go to the nunnery and go forth,”

ai-sn21:9.1.2_0: Then venerable Tissa the Fortunate One’s son approached the Fortunate One,
ai-sn21:9.1.2_1: bowed, sat down to one side, and depressed in pain and depressed.
ai-sn21:9.1.2_2: Then the Fortunate One said this to venerable Tissa:
ai-sn21:9.1.3_0: “Tissa, why are you sitting there so miserable and sad, with tears flowing?”
ai-sn21:9.1.4_0: “Sir, it’s because the mendicants on all sides provoke me with barbed words.”
ai-sn21:9.1.5_0: “That’s because you admonish others, but don’t accept admonition yourself.
ai-sn21:9.1.6_0: As a gentleman who has gone forth in faith from the lay life to homelessness, it’s not appropriate for you to admonish others without accepting admonition yourself.
ai-sn21:9.1.8_0: admonish others and accept admonition yourself.”
ai-sn21:9.2.1_0: That is what the Buddha said.
ai-sn21:9.2.2_0: Then the Holy One, the Teacher, went on to say:
ai-sn21:9.3.1_0: “Why are you angry? Don’t be angry!
ai-sn21:9.3.2_0: It’s better to not be angry, Tissa.
ai-sn21:9.3.4_0: in order to remove anger, conceit, and denigration.”
ai-sn21:10.1.1_0: At one time the Buddha was staying near Rājagaha, in the Bamboo Grove, the squirrels’ feeding ground.
ai-sn21:10.1.2_0: Now at that time a certain senior mendicant lived alone and praises living alone.
ai-sn21:10.1.3_0: He entered the village for alms alone, returned alone, sat in private alone, and concentrated on walking mindfully alone.
ai-sn21:10.1.4_0: Then many monks went to the Fortunate One,
ai-sn21:10.1.4_1: After bowing down to the Buddha, they sat down,
ai-sn21:10.1.5_0: “Sir, there’s a certain mendicant named Senior who lives alone and praises living alone.”

ai-sn21:10.2.4_1: and after going, he said this to the Elder:
ai-sn21:10.2.7_0: “Is it really true, Senior, that you live alone and praise living alone?”
ai-sn21:10.2.9_0: “But in what way do you live alone and praise living alone?”
ai-sn21:10.2.10_0: “Well, sir, I enter the village for alms alone, return alone, sit in private alone, and concentrate on walking mindfully alone.
ai-sn21:10.2.11_0: That’s how I live alone and praise living alone.”
ai-sn21:10.3.1_0: “There is, Senior, I say that there is not even a single one, I say.

ai-sn21:10.3.5_0: “How can the senior monks have fulfilled in detail?
ai-sn21:10.3.6_0: It’s when what’s in the past is given up, what’s in the future is relinquished, and desire and greed for present incarnations is eliminated.
ai-sn21:10.3.7_0: That’s how living alone is fulfilled in detail.”
ai-sn21:10.4.1_0: That is what the Buddha said.
